executive_summary:
Across 2025, ElizaOS substantially expanded capability and modernized its foundations: the plugin ecosystem and AI provider surface grew rapidly, social/real-time clients widened the public-facing footprint, and core architecture moved toward modular, agent-scoped, multi-tenant readiness. The product also matured with a redesigned management UI, better observability, and multiple refactors (eventing, messaging, server separation) that collectively set a stronger baseline for cloud deployment and long-lived agents.

However, the year also revealed a consistent pattern: capability expansion routinely outpaced the stability budget. Onboarding and packaging friction persisted, social integrations (especially Twitter/X) remained a high-cost reliability sink, and RAG ingestion continued to fail under real-world document loads. Operational trust was further stressed by CLI instability episodes and token migration UX/comms gaps. Late-year work (server refactor, TypeScript/CI stabilization, security fixes, early streaming work) meaningfully improved the core, but the “first-run success + boring reliability” loop still needs to become the dominant shipping constraint.

Net: ElizaOS exited 2025 with stronger architecture and broader reach, but leadership should treat 2026 as an execution-and-trust consolidation phase—defined by measurable reliability, secure-by-default multi-user design, and platform-sovereign distribution/communications—so ecosystem growth compounds rather than resets after each regression.

key_achievements.theme: Capability expansion (plugins, chains/DeFi, providers, models, voice)
accomplishments: Expanded cross-chain and infra integrations (Cosmos/IBC swap, TON, Sei, Stargaze; Ankr/Moralis; CoinGecko/CoinMarketCap) increasing builder options and reach.
Broadened AI provider portability and reduced lock-in (Amazon Bedrock, NVIDIA NIM, DeepSeek, Infera, updated Google configs; Kluster AI; Mem0 SDK).
Added voice and media capabilities (OpenAI TTS, ElevenLabs improvements, transcription provider selection) enabling richer agent experiences.
key_achievements.impact: High: increased platform attractiveness and differentiated ElizaOS as a composable agent stack across models and ecosystems.

key_achievements.theme: Core architecture modernization (modularity, eventing, runtime, messaging, server separation)
accomplishments: Implemented dynamic plugin loading and continued provider-to-plugin refactors, reducing core coupling.
Migrated runtime from Node to Bun and core messaging from WebSockets to Socket.io; later standardized messaging APIs and UUID-based agent identification.
Refactored core event system (Evt) and later moved from EventEmitter to EventTarget; introduced action chaining and standardized service interfaces.
Major server separation/refactor and optimization in December to reduce timeout risk and prepare for scale.
key_achievements.impact: High: created the technical prerequisites for cloud deployment, composability, and long-term maintainability—though transitions increased short-term churn.

key_achievements.theme: Product surface improvements (UI, observability, management workflows)
accomplishments: Shipped a major Agent Management UI redesign with streamlined setup, plugin/env configuration, env upload tooling, and memory visibility.
Added in-product observability (agent actions + runtime logs in UI), reducing black-box debugging.
key_achievements.impact: High: improved developer/operator effectiveness and reduced time-to-diagnose failures.

accomplishments: Introduced a separate knowledge system for multi-agent RAG optimization; added scopable knowledge and a foundational world-state provider.
Improved adapter consistency (getMemoryByIds), directory loading, double-byte support; added PgLite adapter.
Delivered partial RAG reliability improvements (OOM guards, splitText safeguards, better fact retrieval).
key_achievements.impact: High: established critical primitives for long-lived agents, though real-world ingestion reliability remains incomplete.

accomplishments: Added/expanded real-time and social clients (Twitter Spaces, Instagram client, XMTP encrypted messaging, Telegram improvements, Discord typing simulation).
Improved Twitter feature completeness (long tweets, delete support) and Telegram supergroup sync/community manager.
key_achievements.impact: High: expanded distribution and visibility, but also amplified reputational risk due to reliability regressions.

key_achievements.theme: Reliability, CI/type safety, and security hardening (late-year)
accomplishments: Resolved widespread TypeScript build issues and dependency upgrades, improving CI health and monorepo integration reliability.
Fixed a critical vulnerability in character secret encryption; advanced entity-level security and settings persistence fixes.
Initiated streaming support across OpenAI/Anthropic/OpenRouter plugins to enable real-time conversational UX.
key_achievements.impact: High: reduced systemic breakage and improved trust posture, while opening the door to “alive” agent UX.

accomplishments: Achieved successful Railway deployment and accelerated cloud platform development.
key_achievements.impact: Medium-to-High: validates deployability, but must be paired with multi-user/auth clarity and operational SLOs.

accomplishments: Launched AI16Z → ElizaOS token migration (1:6 ratio) and opened the migration window.
key_achievements.impact: High (ecosystem trust): strategically necessary transition, but user experience and comms issues reduced upside.

persistent_challenges.root_cause: Frequent architectural shifts (runtime, plugin system, client-vs-plugin conventions), inconsistent environment assumptions (Node/Bun/OS native deps), incomplete packaging discipline (npm publishing gaps), and lack of continuously-tested “golden path” templates.
persistent_challenges.recommendation: Establish a single blessed onboarding path with CI-enforced reproducibility (OS matrix + pinned toolchain), ship it as a versioned artifact (template + lockfile + smoke tests), and treat onboarding regressions as release blockers.

persistent_challenges.issue: Twitter/X integration instability and public-behavior safety risk
persistent_challenges.root_cause: High external API volatility (auth/rate limits/media), insufficient rate-limit/backoff and idempotency guarantees, inadequate safety defaults for posting/reply behavior, and limited contract/integration testing against real-world edge cases.
persistent_challenges.recommendation: Define “gold path” social SLOs, implement strict idempotency + dedupe, safe default posting policies, and a staged rollout (canary accounts + kill switches) with automated monitoring.

persistent_challenges.issue: RAG/knowledge ingestion reliability (OOM, large docs/PDFs, embedding instability)
persistent_challenges.root_cause: Unbounded memory usage during ingestion, inconsistent chunking/embedding contracts across providers, and insufficient deterministic pipelines for large-file processing (PDF parsing, batching, retry semantics).
persistent_challenges.recommendation: Ship a deterministic ingestion pipeline (streaming chunker, bounded concurrency, resumable jobs, canonical embedding dimension management) with hard limits and clear operator feedback.

persistent_challenges.issue: Release discipline gaps and regression cycles under high PR velocity
persistent_challenges.root_cause: High throughput without consistent quality gates, weak compatibility contracts (plugins/providers/adapters), and insufficient fixture-based integration testing across common stack combinations.
persistent_challenges.recommendation: Adopt release gates (smoke tests, upgrade tests, plugin contract tests), enforce semantic versioning policy, and publish migration guides simultaneously with breaking changes.

persistent_challenges.root_cause: CLI treated as a rapidly evolving surface without the same stability guarantees as core runtime; architectural changes outpaced backward compatibility and test coverage.
persistent_challenges.recommendation: Separate CLI “core” (stable) from experimental features, add snapshot tests and end-to-end scaffolding tests, and maintain a strict compatibility policy for one major line.

persistent_challenges.issue: Documentation lag, broken public surfaces, and information taming
persistent_challenges.root_cause: Docs not shipped as a release artifact, high change rate, unclear canonical sources, and insufficient doc ownership/review gates.
persistent_challenges.recommendation: Make docs a versioned deliverable tied to releases (docs PR required for breaking changes), add “known issues” registry, and implement docs uptime/search SLOs.

persistent_challenges.issue: Platform sovereignty and centralized dependency risk (account bans/censorship)
persistent_challenges.root_cause: Over-reliance on centralized social channels for brand and distribution without redundant, censorship-resistant communication pathways.
persistent_challenges.recommendation: Create a platform-sovereign communications and distribution stack (email/RSS, mirrors, signed announcements, decentralized/social alternatives) and ensure critical operations don’t depend on a single platform.

persistent_challenges.issue: Token migration UX/comms and ecosystem trust erosion
persistent_challenges.root_cause: Complex multi-stakeholder coordination (portal, CEX support, documentation), insufficient operational comms discipline (status, SLAs, anti-scam messaging), and unclear single source of truth.
persistent_challenges.recommendation: Run migrations as an ops product: public status page, weekly updates, clear support paths, explicit exchange support matrix, and signed canonical documentation to reduce scams and confusion.

improved.issue: Monorepo TypeScript build stability and CI health
improved.progress: By 2025-12, widespread TS build issues were resolved and dependencies updated, reducing integration friction and improving confidence in merges/releases.

improved.issue: Core architecture readiness for scale (server refactor, messaging/eventing modernization)
improved.progress: 2025-06 through 2025-12 delivered server separation and optimization plus messaging/eventing standardization, improving reliability patterns and maintainability.
2025-03 surfaced actions/logs in UI, shortening debug cycles and making failures more actionable.

improved.issue: Security posture (secrets handling and entity-level security)
improved.progress: Secret salting earlier in the year and a critical encryption vulnerability fixed in 2025-12; entity-level security landed in 2025-11, though auth enforcement still needs follow-through.
Successful Railway deployment (2025-08) and late-year server improvements increased confidence in production deployment paths.

stagnant.blocker: External API volatility plus insufficient idempotency, rate-limit resilience, and test coverage; repeated regressions kept it a visible trust liability all year.
Packaging gaps, native dependency issues across OSes, and shifting conventions; improvements were incremental but not converted into a continuously-tested golden path.

stagnant.issue: RAG ingestion reliability beyond small demos
stagnant.blocker: Large-doc/PDF pipelines remained memory- and parsing-fragile; partial safeguards were added but not a deterministic, resumable ingestion system.
Documentation and public surfaces repeatedly lagged behind shipping velocity; no hard gating ensured docs parity with breaking changes.

stagnant.issue: CLI stability as a product contract
stagnant.blocker: CLI underwent multiple major changes and a crisis/reversion event (2025-09), indicating insufficient testing and compatibility guarantees.

stagnant.issue: Token migration user experience and trust operations
stagnant.blocker: Portal issues, unclear CEX support, and documentation clarity gaps; required stronger operational discipline rather than only technical fixes.

strategic_recommendations.area: Gold Path Reliability: “Hello Agent” that stays working (onboarding + packaging + templates)
strategic_recommendations.rationale: Ecosystem growth is capped by first-run failures; every additional capability has diminishing returns until install/run success is predictable.
strategic_recommendations.success_criteria: ≥90% time-to-first-agent success within 30 minutes across macOS/Linux/Windows (WSL2 acceptable initially); single-command scaffold+run; nightly CI validates templates against pinned toolchains.

strategic_recommendations.area: Release Discipline and Compatibility Contracts (core, CLI, plugins, adapters)
strategic_recommendations.rationale: Velocity without gates produced regressions, reverts, and trust loss; stability must become measurable and enforced.
strategic_recommendations.success_criteria: Pre-release test matrix for top stacks; documented breaking-change policy; regression rate decreases release-over-release; plugin contract tests required for “stable tier” plugins.

strategic_recommendations.area: Social Integrations as a Brand SLO (Twitter/Telegram/Discord ‘boring reliability’)
strategic_recommendations.rationale: Public agents define reputation; failures are externally visible and costly (including account risk).
strategic_recommendations.success_criteria: Defined SLOs (post success rate, duplicate rate, rate-limit recovery time); idempotency/dedupe guarantees; kill switches; canary rollout; incident playbooks.

strategic_recommendations.area: Deterministic RAG/Knowledge Pipeline (bounded memory, resumable ingestion, canonical embeddings)
strategic_recommendations.rationale: Durable agents require durable knowledge. Real deployments will fail until ingestion is reliable for large, messy documents.
strategic_recommendations.success_criteria: Successful ingestion of large PDFs/docs under bounded RAM; resumable job model; embedding dimension mismatches eliminated via canonical configuration; clear operator-facing failure reasons.

strategic_recommendations.area: Secure-by-default, Multi-user by Design (auth, tenancy, permissions, secrets)
strategic_recommendations.rationale: Cloud, marketplace, and serious deployments require coherent multi-tenant security and enforced auth defaults; late-year fixes show both risk and momentum.
strategic_recommendations.success_criteria: Explicit tenant model (user/org/entity/agent); enforced auth token checks by default; secrets never logged; periodic security review cadence; vulnerability response SLA.

strategic_recommendations.area: Docs and Comms as Infrastructure (canonical sources, signed announcements, status discipline)
strategic_recommendations.rationale: Docs lag and token migration confusion show that trust depends on a single source of truth and operational communication, not just code.
strategic_recommendations.success_criteria: Docs required for breaking changes; versioned docs per release; known-issues registry; public status page for incidents/migrations; signed/canonical announcements to reduce phishing and rumor churn.

strategic_recommendations.rationale: The X/Twitter account loss demonstrated centralized platform fragility; decentralization must include comms and distribution channels.
strategic_recommendations.success_criteria: Redundant official channels (mirrors, RSS/email, decentralized socials); verified identity practices; critical updates never depend on a single platform.

current_gaps: “Most reliable” is not operationally defined, making it hard to prioritize tradeoffs and defend the positioning externally.
Docs, onboarding, and migration tooling are not consistently treated as first-class product surfaces with release gates.
Security and multi-user/tenancy design are not yet explicit pillars despite cloud/marketplace ambitions.
Platform sovereignty (censorship resistance) emerged as a strategic requirement but is not reflected in the mission framing.
Community trust operations (clear comms, transparent decisions) are under-specified relative to token and ecosystem realities.
suggested_additions: Measurable reliability (install success, crash-free sessions, integration success rates, deterministic ingestion).
Docs/observability/migrations as release artifacts (versioned, tested, and owned).
Secure-by-default and multi-user by design (tenancy, auth, permissions, secrets).
Community-driven development norms (transparent decision-making and canonical communications).
north_star_evolution.proposed_revision: ElizaOS exists to power a decentralized agent economy by being the most reliable, developer-first, and platform-sovereign agent framework—secure-by-default and multi-user by design—backed by measurable reliability (onboarding success, crash-free operation, integration SLOs, deterministic knowledge ingestion) and shipped with first-class docs, observability, and migration tooling as versioned release artifacts.

metrics_to_track.metric: Time-to-First-Agent (TTFA) success rate (<=30 min) by OS
metrics_to_track.why: Directly measures onboarding reality and ecosystem conversion.
metrics_to_track.target: ≥90% success on macOS/Linux; ≥80% on Windows/WSL2; improve quarterly.

metrics_to_track.metric: Install/build reproducibility (CI green rate for templates across OS/toolchain matrix)
metrics_to_track.why: Prevents regressions from landing and validates the golden path continuously.

metrics_to_track.metric: Crash-free sessions (runtime) and error budget consumption
metrics_to_track.why: Operational definition of “most reliable” at runtime.

metrics_to_track.metric: Social integration SLOs (post success rate, duplicate post rate, rate-limit recovery time)
metrics_to_track.why: Public brand and trust depend on boring reliability and safe behavior.
metrics_to_track.target: Post success ≥99%; duplicates ≤0.1%; recovery time p95 ≤5 min.

metrics_to_track.metric: RAG ingestion success rate for large documents (e.g., 50–200MB PDFs) under bounded RAM
metrics_to_track.why: Gates real deployments; demo-only ingestion undermines platform claims.
metrics_to_track.target: ≥95% success on reference workload; bounded memory within defined limits.

metrics_to_track.metric: Regression rate per release (P0/P1 incidents within 7 days of release)
metrics_to_track.why: Measures release discipline effectiveness and stability trajectory.
metrics_to_track.target: Reduce by 50% over two quarters; maintain downward trend.

metrics_to_track.metric: Docs freshness and coverage (docs PR required for breaking changes; % of top workflows documented)
metrics_to_track.why: Docs are infrastructure; lag creates support burden and trust loss.
metrics_to_track.target: 100% of breaking changes documented at release; ≥90% of top-10 workflows covered.

metrics_to_track.metric: Security posture (vuln remediation SLA; secret leakage incidents)
metrics_to_track.why: Cloud and ecosystem trust depend on predictable security operations.
metrics_to_track.target: Critical fixes <72 hours; zero known secret leakage incidents per quarter.

metrics_to_track.metric: Plugin ecosystem health (stable-tier count, contract test pass rate, maintainer coverage)
metrics_to_track.why: Controls plugin sprawl while preserving ecosystem growth.
metrics_to_track.target: 100% stable-tier plugins have maintainer + contract tests; pass rate ≥95%.

metrics_to_track.metric: Token migration operations (completion rate, support ticket volume, mean time to resolution, scam incident rate)
metrics_to_track.why: Trust infrastructure for the ecosystem; operational clarity reduces reputational bleed.
metrics_to_track.target: High completion rate within window; MTTR <48 hours; scam incidents trending to zero via signed comms and clear UX.
